SubTopics: Conduct an investigation to provide evidence that living things are made of cells; either one cell or many different numbers and types of cells.
Content: During the microscope investigation, the students observed the amoeba and euglena
The observations on the amoeba and euglena provide evidence that

A.Choice: cells are a part of tissues

B.Choice: cells rely on other cells for survival

C.Choice: living things can be composed of one cell

D.Choice: water and oxygen are used by the cell to produce energy

SubTopics: Conduct an investigation to provide evidence that living things are made of cells; either one cell or many different numbers and types of cells.
Content: During the microscope investigation, the students observed cells
Evidence from the investigation supports the classification of humans and onions as

A.Choice: unicellular organisms that have cells for different tissues

B.Choice: unicellular organisms that have cells that work independently

C.Choice: multicellular organisms that have different types of cells with specialized functions

D.Choice: multicellular organisms that have cells that use the same organelle for protection and structure

SubTopics: Conduct an investigation to provide evidence that living things are made of cells; either one cell or many different numbers and types of cells.
Content: The students continued using the microscope and compared table salt to the onion cells they previously observed. A diagram of the table salt is shown below.
problems/MDG8S/media/3a.jpg
Using observations from their investigation, the students classified the salt as

A.Choice: living, because the salt has cells

B.Choice: living, because the salt has atoms

C.Choice: nonliving, because the salt lacks cells

D.Choice: nonliving, because the salt lacks atoms

SubTopics: Use argument supported by evidence for how the body is a system of interacting subsystems composed of groups of cells.
Content: The students' research indicated that heart muscle cells are only one type of cell in the circulatory system and that the circulatory system is composed of several organs working together.
Which other circulatory system organ works directly with the heart to ensure other body tissues receive oxygen?

A.Choice: brain

B.Choice: kidneys

C.Choice: lung nodules

D.Choice: blood vessels

SubTopics: Use argument supported by evidence for how the body is a system of interacting subsystems composed of groups of cells.
Content: The students' research indicated that the human body is composed of cells
Which table lists each body structure in order of least complex organization to most complex organization?

A.Choice: problems/MDG8S/media/5a.jpg

B.Choice: problems/MDG8S/media/5b.jpg

C.Choice: problems/MDG8S/media/5c.jpg

D.Choice: problems/MDG8S/media/5d.jpg

SubTopics: Use argument supported by evidence for how the body is a system of interacting subsystems composed of groups of cells.
Content: The students found that intestinal cells are part of an organ in the digestive system.
Use evidence to explain how the intestinal cells help the intestines work within the digestive system. In your explanation, be sure to include

:ibox:• the role of the intestines in the digestive system

• the interacting components in the intestines

SubTopics: Develop a model to describe the cycling of water through Earth's systems driven by energy from the sun and the force of gravity.
Content: The students used their model to better understand how water moves through the water cycle
Which phenomenon causes precipitation to reach Earth?

A.Choice: solar energy

B.Choice: magnetic force

C.Choice: potential energy

D.Choice: gravitational force

SubTopics: Construct a scientific explanation based on evidence for how the uneven distributions of Earth's mineral, energy, and groundwater resources are the result of past and current geoscience processes.
Content: THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
The students reviewed a list of materials and began to classify them as renewable or nonrenewable resources
Which materials can be classified as renewable resources?
Select all that apply.

A.Choice: coal

B.Choice: metal

C.Choice: oil

D.Choice: sunlight

Content: The difference between renewable and nonrenewable resources is that nonrenewable resources require

A.Choice: less material to make than renewable resources

B.Choice: more material to make than renewable resources

C.Choice: less time to naturally occur than renewable resources

D.Choice: more time to naturally occur than renewable resources

SubTopics: Develop a model to describe the cycling of water through Earth's systems driven by energy from the sun and the force of gravity.
Content: After constructing their model, the students found that water is stored in many different water systems.
Which water systems store liquid water after it falls as precipitation?
Select all that apply.

A.Choice: aquifers

B.Choice: atmosphere

C.Choice: clouds

D.Choice: lakes

SubTopics: Construct a scientific explanation based on evidence for how the uneven distributions of Earth's mineral, energy, and groundwater resources are the result of past and current geoscience processes.
Content: The students found that in Maryland some aquifers exist beneath the Ridge and Valley region.
Aquifers form in this region of the state because limestone is

A.Choice: porous and composed of sediment

B.Choice: volcanic and composed of cooled magma

C.Choice: nonporous and composed of folded metamorphic rock

D.Choice: sedimentary and composed of crystallized igneous rock

SubTopics: Construct a scientific explanation based on evidence for how the uneven distributions of Earth's mineral, energy, and groundwater resources are the result of past and current geoscience processes.
Content: Some of the fractured rock that makes up naturally occurring wells in the Appalachian Plateau region of Maryland is composed of sandstone. This type of rock was formed through

A.Choice: volcanic activity

B.Choice: sediments compacting over time

C.Choice: folding and squeezing of rock layers

D.Choice: extreme pressure on and heating of rock layers

SubTopics: Construct a scientific explanation based on evidence for how the uneven distributions of Earth's mineral, energy, and groundwater resources are the result of past and current geoscience processes.
Content: The students found that some of the locations on the Maryland groundwater map currently have above normal water levels. However, these locations have also experienced periods of drought in the past five years.
Use evidence to explain how water can be depleted and refilled in such a short period of time.

SubTopics: Develop models to describe the atomic composition of simple molecules and extended structures.
Content: The students found that the volume of water increased when it froze. They constructed a model of liquid and frozen water, shown below, to illustrate how phase affects water molecule arrangement.
problems/MDG8S/media/13a.jpg
The volume of water increases when water freezes because

A.Choice: water molecules have a low density

B.Choice: the components of a water molecule increase in mass

C.Choice: the arrangement of the molecules in the water changes

D.Choice: water molecules are composed of atoms from different elements

SubTopics: Develop models to describe the atomic composition of simple molecules and extended structures.
Content: The students used the models to better understand the structure of table sugar.
Table sugar is composed of

A.Choice: carbon dioxide (CO₂) and water (H₂O) atoms

B.Choice: carbon (C), hydrogen (H), and oxygen (O) atoms

C.Choice: carbon dioxide (CO₂) and water (H₂O) molecules

D.Choice: carbon (C), hydrogen (H), and oxygen (O) molecules

SubTopics: Develop models to describe the atomic composition of simple molecules and extended structures.
Content: The students used the model of a water molecule to better understand its structure
Water is classified as a molecule because it

A.Choice: is composed of multiple atoms that are chemically bonded

B.Choice: changes phases when exposed to thermal energy

C.Choice: is composed of elements that are gases

D.Choice: has mass and takes up space

SubTopics: Develop models to describe the atomic composition of simple molecules and extended structures.
Content: The students compared the models of a table sugar molecule and a water molecule
How do table sugar molecules differ from water molecules?

A.Choice: A table sugar molecule is a mixture.

B.Choice: A water molecule is a pure substance.

C.Choice: Water molecules may repeat to form extended structures.

D.Choice: Table sugar molecules may repeat to form extended structures.

SubTopics: Develop a model that predicts and describes changes in particle motion, temperature, and state of a pure substance when thermal energy is added or removed.
Content: In the thermometer model, the liquid expanded because

A.Choice: the chemical energy of a liquid's molecules changes proportionally to the change in phase

B.Choice: the potential energy of a liquid's molecules changes proportionally to the change in volume

C.Choice: the potential energy of a liquid's molecules changes proportionally to the change in temperature

D.Choice: the average kinetic energy of a liquid's molecules changes proportionally to the change in temperature

SubTopics: Develop a model that predicts and describes changes in particle motion, temperature, and state of a pure substance when thermal energy is added or removed.
Content: Use evidence from the investigation to explain what causes water to change phases. In your explanation be sure to include

:ibox:• the transfer of energy

• the molecular structure

SubTopics: Develop and use a model to describe why asexual reproduction results in offspring with identical genetic information and sexual reproduction results in offspring with genetic variation.
Content: The students constructed a Punnett square for corals that illustrates the transmission of the trait that allows the corals to live in warm water.
problems/MDG8S/media/19a.jpg
Coral polyps X and Y are

A.Choice: the parents and have identical allele pairs

B.Choice: the parents and have different allele pairs

C.Choice: the offspring and have identical allele pairs

D.Choice: the offspring and have different allele pairs

SubTopics: Develop and use a model to describe why asexual reproduction results in offspring with identical genetic information and sexual reproduction results in offspring with genetic variation.
Content: The students' research indicated that one species of coral has 28 chromosomes
Which table best describes the m͟o͟s͟t͟ ͟l͟i͟k͟e͟l͟y number of chromosomes in coral parents and offspring during sexual reproduction?

A.Choice: problems/MDG8S/media/20a.jpg

B.Choice: problems/MDG8S/media/20b.jpg

C.Choice: problems/MDG8S/media/20c.jpg

D.Choice: problems/MDG8S/media/20d.jpg

SubTopics: Construct an explanation based on evidence that describes how genetic variations of traits in a population increase some individuals' probability of surviving and reproducing in a specific environment.
Content: The students continued their research to determine how different coral colonies interact with one another.
What method of reproduction do corals use when different colonies reproduce with one another?

A.Choice: asexual reproduction, which will most likely cause a decrease in potential traits

B.Choice: sexual reproduction, which will most likely cause an increase in genetic variation

C.Choice: asexual reproduction, which will most likely cause a decrease in stress from bleaching

D.Choice: sexual reproduction, which will most likely cause an increase in temperature sensitivity

SubTopics: Construct an explanation based on evidence that describes how genetic variations of traits in a population increase some individuals' probability of surviving and reproducing in a specific environment.
Content: The students' research indicated that corals that can survive in water over 31 degrees Celsius (°C) have a greater likelihood of surviving bleaching events.
If coral polyps only breed with corals that carry this temperature trait, the offspring they produce will m͟o͟s͟t͟ ͟l͟i͟k͟e͟l͟y have

A.Choice: an increased likelihood of carrying the temperature trait

B.Choice: a decreased likelihood of passing on the temperature trait

C.Choice: a decreased likelihood of surviving future bleaching events

D.Choice: an increased likelihood of experiencing future bleaching events

SubTopics: Construct an explanation based on evidence that describes how genetic variations of traits in a population increase some individuals' probability of surviving and reproducing in a specific environment.
Content: THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
The research indicated that there are coral species that live much deeper in the ocean and prefer to live in cool water below 19 degrees Celsius (°C).
If a cool-water coral species were moved to a shallow reef near the equator, the corals would m͟o͟s͟t͟ ͟l͟i͟k͟e͟l͟y

A.Choice: survive in the warmer water

B.Choice: adapt to the warmer water

C.Choice: reproduce in the warmer water

D.Choice: become bleached in the warmer water

Content: According to the students' research, which are the m͟o͟s͟t͟ ͟l͟i͟k͟e͟l͟y effects to coral populations if ocean temperatures continue to increase?
Select all that apply.

A.Choice: a population increase

B.Choice: a population decrease

C.Choice: a lower chance of survival

D.Choice: a greater chance of survival

SubTopics: Develop and use a model to describe why asexual reproduction results in offspring with identical genetic information and sexual reproduction results in offspring with genetic variation.
Content: The students modified an existing model they had made to predict how breeding between coral polyps with a trait that allows the corals to live in warm water would be transmitted.
problems/MDG8S/media/24a.jpg
Use evidence to explain why corals use this method of reproduction to produce offspring to form new reef colonies.

SubTopics: nalyze and interpret data on the distribution of fossils and rocks, continental shapes, and seafloor structures to provide evidence of the past plate motions.
Content: The students found that scientists used the data from the mid-Atlantic ridge to support the claim that continent shape and location change over time due to tectonic plate movement.
Which data b͟e͟s͟t supports this claim?

A.Choice: the rate at which the plates are moving near the ridge

B.Choice: the age of the sediment and its distance from the ridge

C.Choice: the amount of sediment and its direction from the ridge

D.Choice: the direction in which the plates are moving near the ridge

SubTopics: nalyze and interpret data on the distribution of fossils and rocks, continental shapes, and seafloor structures to provide evidence of the past plate motions.
Content: The students' research indicated that Lystrosaurus was a slow-moving, plant-eating reptile that lived over 250 million years ago.
The supporting evidence that Lystrosaurus inhabited a single landmass that broke apart is that fossils of Lystrosaurus are found

A.Choice: on different landmasses

B.Choice: on glacial ice shelves

C.Choice: in seafloor trenches

D.Choice: in the oceanic crust

SubTopics: nalyze and interpret data on the distribution of fossils and rocks, continental shapes, and seafloor structures to provide evidence of the past plate motions.
Content: The students found that the mid-Atlantic ridge data were used to support a scientist's claim that new crust forms at ridges.
Which graph b͟e͟s͟t represents the mid-Atlantic ridge data?

A.Choice: problems/MDG8S/media/27a.jpg

B.Choice: problems/MDG8S/media/27b.jpg

C.Choice: problems/MDG8S/media/27c.jpg

D.Choice: problems/MDG8S/media/27d.jpg

SubTopics: Construct a scientific explanation based on evidence from rock strata for how the geologic time scale is used to organize Earth's 4.6-billion-year-old history.
Content: After examining the tectonic plate maps, the students determined where the plate boundaries exist on Earth
Some mountain ranges occur along plate boundaries.
Future plate movement will m͟o͟s͟t͟ ͟l͟i͟k͟e͟l͟y result in these mountains

A.Choice: staying the same size because the plates slide past one another

B.Choice: decreasing in size because the plates will slide past one another

C.Choice: increasing in size because the plates will collide with one another

D.Choice: staying the same size because the plates separate from one another

SubTopics: Construct a scientific explanation based on evidence from rock strata for how the geologic time scale is used to organize Earth's 4.6-billion-year-old history.
Content: A student observed the plate boundary map and found that active volcanoes form where two plates currently meet. The student stated that extinct volcanoes are likely found where plates met in the past and wanted to determine if the past eruptions of the extinct volcanoes could be used as evidence of plate motion.
Which evidence found in and around extinct volcanoes would best support the concept of plate motion?

A.Choice: lava fields forming near coastlines on different continents

B.Choice: lava fields forming near mountain ranges on different continents

C.Choice: a large volume of ash appearing in different rock strata on different continents

D.Choice: a large volume of ash appearing in the same rock strata on different continents

SubTopics: Construct a scientific explanation based on evidence from rock strata for how the geologic time scale is used to organize Earth's 4.6-billion-year-old history.
Content: The students' research indicated that continents on Earth have changed position over time.
Use evidence to explain how the continents on Earth have changed position in the past and how the continents will m͟o͟s͟t͟ ͟l͟i͟k͟e͟l͟y continue to change in the future.

SubTopics: Construct and present arguments using evidence to support the claim that gravitational interactions are attractive and depend on the masses of interacting objects.
Content: After researching the orbits of asteroids in the solar system, students explained that in order for asteroids in the asteroid belt to remain in orbit,

A.Choice: Earth must exert a strong gravitational force toward the center of the solar system

B.Choice: the sun must exert a strong gravitational force toward the center of the solar system

C.Choice: Earth must exert a strong gravitational force away from the center of the solar system

D.Choice: the sun must exert a strong gravitational force away from the center of the solar system

SubTopics: Apply Newton's Third Law to design a solution to a problem involving the motion of two colliding objects.
Content: The students used evidence to present an argument that scientists should launch an unmanned spacecraft to prevent a collision between an asteroid and Earth's moon
In order for the spacecraft to prevent the asteroid from colliding with the moon, the spacecraft would m͟o͟s͟t͟ ͟l͟i͟k͟e͟l͟y

A.Choice: have a smaller mass than the mass of the asteroid

B.Choice: have enough force to knock the asteroid off course

C.Choice: reduce its speed to match the speed of the asteroid

D.Choice: spin in a forward direction to alter the orbit of the asteroid

SubTopics: Construct and present arguments using evidence to support the claim that gravitational interactions are attractive and depend on the masses of interacting objects.
Content: Evidence indicates that some asteroids have moons that are held in orbit by a gravitational attraction between the moon and the asteroid.
Which table correctly sequences the asteroids in order of the gravitational attraction exerted by each asteroid?

A.Choice: problems/MDG8S/media/33a.jpg

B.Choice: problems/MDG8S/media/33b.jpg

C.Choice: problems/MDG8S/media/33c.jpg

D.Choice: problems/MDG8S/media/33d.jpg

SubTopics: Construct and present arguments using evidence to support the claim that gravitational interactions are attractive and depend on the masses of interacting objects.
Content: THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
Data from the students' research indicated that some asteroids are orbited by other asteroids.
Which asteroid would m͟o͟s͟t͟ ͟l͟i͟k͟e͟l͟y͟ be orbited by other asteroids?

A.Choice: Itokawa

B.Choice: Juno

C.Choice: Mathilde

D.Choice: Vesta

Content: The explanation that b͟e͟s͟t describes why one asteroid would orbit another asteroid is that the asteroid being orbited has a large

A.Choice: mass, which results in a strong gravitational force

B.Choice: metallic core, which results in a strong magnetic field

C.Choice: diameter, which results in a strong gravitational force

D.Choice: amount of iron, which results in a strong magnetic field

SubTopics: Construct and present arguments using evidence to support the claim that gravitational interactions are attractive and depend on the masses of interacting objects.
Content: Based on the evidence from the research, at which point in Golevka's orbit would the Yarkovsky effect be the weakest?
problems/MDG8S/media/35a.jpg

SubTopics: Construct and present arguments using evidence to support the claim that gravitational interactions are attractive and depend on the masses of interacting objects.
Content: Asteroids orbit other asteroids similarly to moons orbiting a planet. The table below identifies the mass of Earth and Jupiter and the number of moons for each planet.
problems/MDG8S/media/36a.jpg
Use evidence to explain why there is a difference in the number of moons between Earth and Jupiter.

SubTopics: Apply scientific principles to design, construct, and test a device that either minimizes or maximizes thermal energy transfer.
Content: Which statements b͟e͟s͟t describe the purpose of the design of the investigational device?
Select all that apply.

A.Choice: The design allows the thermometer to be moved so the temperature can be measured.

B.Choice: The design maximizes the thermal energy transferred from the water to the metal.

C.Choice: The design minimizes the thermal energy transferred to the outside environment.

D.Choice: The design provides the initial thermal energy for the metal samples.

E.Choice: The design ensures the metal-water device is a closed system.

SubTopics: Apply scientific principles to design, construct, and test a device that either minimizes or maximizes thermal energy transfer.
Content: Which property of the metals used in the investigation is m͟o͟s͟t͟ ͟l͟i͟k͟e͟l͟y the reason the student chose to use metal cubes

A.Choice: large mass

B.Choice: small volume

C.Choice: low malleability

D.Choice: high conductivity

SubTopics: Plan an investigation to determine the relationships among the energy transferred, the type of matter, the mass, and the change in the average kinetic energy of the particles as measured by the temperature of the sample.
Content: What is the m͟o͟s͟t͟ ͟l͟i͟k͟e͟l͟y reason the student waited until the temperature no longer changed to record the data

A.Choice: to make sure that the water did not start to boil

B.Choice: to have time to calculate the change in temperature

C.Choice: to allow the transfer of thermal energy to be complete

D.Choice: to observe that the temperature of the water was affected by the metal cube

SubTopics: Plan an investigation to determine the relationships among the energy transferred, the type of matter, the mass, and the change in the average kinetic energy of the particles as measured by the temperature of the sample.
Content: The data from the investigation showed that after each metal cube was placed into the water

A.Choice: the temperature of the water increased, and the kinetic energy of the water molecules increased

B.Choice: the temperature of the water decreased, and the kinetic energy of the water molecules decreased

C.Choice: the temperature of the water remained the same, and the kinetic energy of the water molecules increased

D.Choice: the temperature of the water decreased, and the kinetic energy of the water molecules remained the same

SubTopics: Construct, use, and present arguments to support the claim that when the kinetic energy of an object changes, energy is transferred to or from the object.
Content: Which phrases describe the types of energy present in the cubes after being placed in the water?
Select all that apply.

A.Choice: Kinetic energy was less.

B.Choice: Thermal energy was less.

C.Choice: Kinetic energy was greater.

D.Choice: Thermal energy was greater.

SubTopics: Construct, use, and present arguments to support the claim that when the kinetic energy of an object changes, energy is transferred to or from the object.
Content: A student claimed that thermal energy was transferred from the water to the metal in the investigation.
Use evidence from the investigation to refute or support this claim.

SubTopics: Develop a model to describe the cycling of matter and flow of energy among living and nonliving parts of an ecosystem.
Content: The prairie food web illustrates interactions among organisms that live in the prairie ecosystem.
Select the table that correctly identifies each organism in the food web as a producer or a consumer.

A.Choice: problems/MDG8S/media/43a.jpg

B.Choice: problems/MDG8S/media/43b.jpg

C.Choice: problems/MDG8S/media/43c.jpg

D.Choice: problems/MDG8S/media/43d.jpg

SubTopics: Develop a model to describe the cycling of matter and flow of energy among living and nonliving parts of an ecosystem.
Content: The prairie food web diagram illustrates interactions among organisms that live in the prairie ecosystem.
Which statement b͟e͟s͟t describes the sources of energy for the producers and consumers in the food web?

A.Choice: Consumers and producers both obtain energy from decomposers.

B.Choice: Consumers gain energy from the sun, while producers obtain energy by eating other organisms.

C.Choice: Producers obtain energy from living organisms, while consumers obtain energy from the nonliving parts of the ecosystem.

D.Choice: Producers use the sun and nonliving parts of the ecosystem to generate energy, while consumers gain energy from other living organisms.

SubTopics: Develop a model to describe the cycling of matter and flow of energy among living and nonliving parts of an ecosystem.
Content: The prairie food web diagram illustrates interactions among organisms that live in the prairie ecosystem.
The arrows in the food web represent

A.Choice: the movement of one organism into the territory of another organism

B.Choice: the transfer of energy from one organism to another

C.Choice: a parasitic interaction between two organisms

D.Choice: a genetic similarity between two organisms

SubTopics: Analyze and interpret data to provide evidence for the effects of resource availability on organisms and populations of organisms in an ecosystem.
Content: The research stated that the prairie dog and ferret interact with one another in the prairie ecosystem.
Which graph b͟e͟s͟t represents the changes in the amount of grass and prairie dog population when the initial number of ferrets in the ecosystem was 140?
problems/MDG8S/media/46a.jpg

A.Choice: problems/MDG8S/media/46b.jpg

B.Choice: problems/MDG8S/media/46c.jpg

C.Choice: problems/MDG8S/media/46d.jpg

D.Choice: problems/MDG8S/media/46e.jpg

SubTopics: Construct an explanation that predicts patterns of interactions among organisms across multiple ecosystems.
Content: The prairie organisms' interactions illustrate the interactions that occur among three different organisms and the prairie dog.
The interaction between the prairie dog and the grasshopper is

A.Choice: competitive because the prairie dog consumes the same resources as the grasshopper

B.Choice: parasitic because the prairie dog has nutrients taken from it by the grasshopper

C.Choice: mutualistic because the prairie dog receives resources from the grasshopper

D.Choice: predatory because the prairie dog tracks and hunts the grasshopper

SubTopics: Analyze and interpret data to provide evidence for the effects of resource availability on organisms and populations of organisms in an ecosystem.
Content: The three prairie food web resources illustrate the interactions among organisms in the prairie ecosystem.
Describe how the prairie dog and bison populations will m͟o͟s͟t͟ ͟l͟i͟k͟e͟l͟y change if a severe drought were to occur for a four-year period. In your description, be sure to includejpg

:ibox:• the cause of any changes to the populations

• the movement of energy within the ecosystem

• the interactions among the organisms
